The Facility has recently applied to Cal OSHA for certification as a Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) Star site, and completed the on-site inspection process in Sept. of 2019.   Specific examples of planned improvements efforts include:

-  Initiating a program of Corporate PHA facilitation to ensure consistent application of corporate risk reduction practices,  
-  Application of a Pump Consequence Evaluation Tool (PCET) for risk reduction around potential high-consequence pump scenarios, and
-  An enhanced human reliability program is being developed for application to procedures development and review efforts.

At the Santa Maria Facility, the pursuit of improved personnel and process safety performance is never satisfied.  The goal of continuous improvement pushes us forward on a never-ending effort to identify and implement effective program enhancements to improve the safety, health, and environmental quality of our workforce and our community.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

FACILITY OVERVIEW & REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) requires companies such as Phillips 66 to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for any processes containing regulated substances above a threshold quantity (TQ); this applies to the Santa Maria Facility.  The Santa Maria Facility handles hazardous materials onsite and recognizes a responsibility to safely operate the facility in order to protect the employees, surrounding community, and the environment.  The Facility has taken a proactive stance to promote the overall safe operation of the processes, with programs to prevent accidents from occurring, planning for emergencies, and maintaining the equipment needed if an emergency does occur.  This RMP formalizes existing programs and procedures so that these programs may be reviewed more efficiently.

The Santa Maria Facility processes crude oil into intermediate products for further processing at other locations to produce transportation fuels.  The Facility receives crude oil from many sources via pipeline or truck, stores it in tanks onsite, and processes the crude oil into products to be shipped elsewhere by pipeline, railcar, and truck.  The refining process separates the crude oil into four products: gas oil, naphtha (pressure distillate), sulfur, and coke (solid carbon-based material).  The sulfur is generated because oil contains significant quantities of sulfur that must be removed to produce low sulfur transportation fuels for the California markets. The gas oil and naphtha products are also stored in the Facility's Storage Tanks prior to shipping by pipeline, while the solid sulfur and solid coke are shipped offsite by truck or railcar.  Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S) gas is also present in some process equipment as a by-product of the refining process. The Facility also has the utility and support systems required to provide for safe operation of the plant, including a power generation

facility to make use of gas generated in the Refining Process.

Santa Maria Facility's Refining & Offplot Units are covered by EPA RMP with the Regulated Substance Class of Flammables over the TQ at Program Level 1.  

Development of the RMP submittal involved identification of Process Units, and their inventories of regulated materials.  Modeling of Worst Case release Scenarios (WCS) was conducted to identify the potential for onsite processes to affect the surrounding community and the environment.  The submittal includes the identification of prevention program elements, a summary of the emergency response program, and development of an executive summary. 


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The following is a summary of the general Accident & Release Prevention Programs in place at the Santa Maria Facility.  The site is also regulated by Cal-OSHA and CalARP for Process Safety Management which has many similar requirements, so the terms PSM and RMP are used interchangeably in these program descriptions.  This summary addresses the applicable RMP elements and describes the management systems in place to implement the accident prevention program.  Each section below contains a brief summary of the prevention program elements and identifies the department responsible for implementation.  


EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

The Santa Maria Facility encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. The program actively involves employees in the elements of PSM, Risk Management, and Loss Control Programs. Examples of employee participation include the following:

-  Introductory and refresher training for all Facility personnel regarding the hazards of the process and process safety management
-  Operator preparation and annual review of written operating procedures
-  Operations participation in various Process Hazard Analyses at the Facility
-  Job-specific training programs for employees, including

safe work practices
-  Regular Safety Meetings on pertinent topics at the Facility
-  Operations and Maintenance participation in incident investigations
-  Review of Management of Change projects by personnel in Technical Services, Operations, and Maintenance
-  A unified Emergency Response Program and inclusion of various personnel in annual drills

PSM and RMP related documents are available to personnel through the Facility's computer network or through hard copy documents. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in the PSM Program and Loss Control Procedures.  The Facility also utilizes its Joint Labor-Management Health and Safety Committee to participate in the requirements outlined by PSM. The Health & Safety Department is responsible for administering the Employee Participation portion of the Prevention Program.


PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

The Santa Maria Facility keeps technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.  The Facility utilizes a computer-based document management system known as Livelink. Livelink enables personnel to access documentation required for RMP/PSM.  The Livelink system operates through the Facility's computer network and is accessible from many computer terminals throughout the Facility.  It is the Facility's goal to make the Process Safety Information easily accessible to personnel as required by PSM and RMP.  Personnel have been trained about the basics of navigating the Livelink system, and anyone having trouble is directed to seek assistance from their supervisor or any member of the Health and Safety department.  Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDS).  SDSs are available through the Phillips 66 on-line SDS system.  The Facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the desi

gn and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment, etc.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and Facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.  Process Safety Information is updated regularly as part of the MOC process, and procedures are updated as part of the procedure review.  Process drawings are maintained by the Drafting Department and are available for viewing on the Livelink system.  Process Safety Information is made available for any Process Hazard Analysis conducted at the Facility. The Technical Services and Operations Departments are responsible for implementing the Process Safety Information portion of the Prevention Program.


PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS (PHA)

The Santa Maria Facility has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each unit is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.  The PHA team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary. The Santa Maria Facility uses the Hazard and Operability Analysis (HazOp) and Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA) techniques to perform these evaluations.

LOPA is a semi-quantitative risk assessment methodology whose purpose is to quantify through simple orders of magnitude the likelihood of high consequence scenarios by ensuring sufficient independent layers of protection.  LOPA uses a calculation to measure the adequacy of existing safegu

ards (e.g. alarms, relief valves, and control loops) compared to the potential consequence. Safeguards identified by the LOPA risk assessment that meet the requirements of effectiveness, independence and auditability are identified as Independent Protection Layers (IPLs). 

HazOp and LOPA analysis are recognized as two of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques.  PHAs are conducted using a team of people who have operating and engineering experience.  At a minimum, the PHA Team consists of at least three full time members:  a PHA Leader with process industry experience and training in HazOp and LOPA methodology, an Operations representative, and a Process Engineer.  Other team members are included as needed.  These members may include personnel from Maintenance, Project Managers, and Contractors. The PHA Team recommendations are reviewed and tracked using our Facility's IMPACT database system.  The appropriate Facility Engineering and Operations personnel review the recommendations from the PHA for their feasibility and impact. The Facility revalidates the Unit PHAs every five years.  The PHA revalidation process incorporates any changes that occurred in the unit during the last five years and also reviews any incidents that occurred in the unit.  The Facility PHA Coordinator maintains a list of the Units and their respective revalidation dates.  The Facility also utilizes a computer program (PHAPro) specifically programmed to document the Process Hazard Analyses.  For each PHA, the Operations representative and other inexperienced PHA Team members are given HazOp and LOPA introductory training and receive guidance from the PHA Team Leader of their PHA responsibilities.  PHA documents are available for review on the Livelink system and from the PHA Coordinator. The Health & Safety Department is responsible for implementing the Process Hazard Analysis portion of the Prevention Program.


OPERATING PROCEDURES

The Santa Maria Facility main

tains written procedures for Operations and Maintenance that address all modes of process operations, including Unit startup, normal operations, shutdown, and emergency shutdown.  Operating Procedures serve as a basis for training and operation of the Units and ensure that the process is operated consistently and safely by personnel.  As part of the Operations Administration Procedure, the Facility reviews and updates the procedures to ensure that they are accurate and reflect the current state of operation and process improvement. The scheduled procedure review addresses at a minimum:

     - Current operating practices, including changes that result from changes to process chemicals, technology and equipment.
     - Operating Limits including consequences of process deviation and steps necessary to avoid deviation.
     - Safety and health considerations, including: 
     - Properties of, and hazards presented by, chemicals in the process
     - Precautions necessary to prevent exposure, including Personal Protective Equipment, engineering controls, and administrative controls
     - Quality control of raw materials and control of hazardous chemical inventory
     - Special or unique hazards
     - Safety systems and their functions
     - Hazard control during operation, including lockout/tagout, hot work, confined space entry, and opening process equipment or piping.

The Santa Maria Facility Management of Change program also includes a provision to ensure that any procedures modified by changes in the process are completed prior to implementation of the change.  Operating Personnel are notified any time a new procedure is issued, or an existing procedure is modified.  Operating Procedures are available to Facility personnel through the online Livelink system.  Additionally, hard copies of Emergency Operating Procedures are available at specified locations in the event of a power interruption. The Operations Department is responsible for implementing

the Operating Procedures portion of the Prevention Program.


HUMAN FACTORS PROGRAM

The Facility's Human Factors Program describes the process to manage Human Factors, aligning the design of machines, operations and work environments such that they closely match human capabilities, limitations, and needs.  Human factors include environmental, organizational and job factors, as well as human and individual characteristics that can affect job and job factors, as well as human and individual characteristics, such as fatigue, that can affect job performance, process safety, and health and safety. The consideration of Human Factors applies to many programs, and are incorporated into the considerations of the following programs:

-  Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) reviews
-  Management of Change (MOC) (for major changes)
-  Management of Organizational Change (MOOC)
-  Incident Investigation (for actual or potential major incidents)
-  Operating Procedures
-  Mechanical Integrity (re. maintenance procedures)

The Health & Safety Department is responsible for implementing the Human Factors portion of the Prevention Program.


TRAINING

The Facility believes that well-trained Operators help ensure safe operation of the Process Units.  The Facility's training program requires employees to qualify in the operation a Process Unit prior to being assigned to work unsupervised in that unit, to understand the nature and causes of problems arising from process operation, and to elevate their awareness with respect to hazards of operating the processes.  Each employee assigned to a Process Unit proceeds sequentially through a planned training program to familiarize new personnel, and personnel transferring from another unit, with unit operations.  Personnel are not assigned to work jobs that they are unqualified to perform. Personnel must proceed through a structured, performance-based training system prior to operating the units.  After initial unit qualification

, operators continue to learn operation of other units in order to become more versatile and aware of other processes at the Facility.  The training program consists of the following steps:
 
-  Initial Training
-  Initial Training Testing
-  Job Specific Training
-  Job Specific On-The-Job Training Equipment Check-off
-  Job Specific Written/Practical Demonstration Test
-  Job Specific Refresher Training

Operators must pass both the Qualification Test and Performance Test when qualifying for a unit.  The Qualification Test consists of a written test pertaining to the unit Process, procedures, health hazards, and safety on the job.  The Performance Test is a field test administered to determine if an employee can transfer written knowledge acquired to the actual hands-on tasks in the field.  Tests and training materials are maintained in personnel files.  Prior to assignment at a unit, Management and the Operator's Supervisor sign-off that the affected Operator is prepared to work the unit by reviewing with the Operator both the written and in-the-field tests. A general outline for initial and refresher training for personnel includes:

I.   An overview of the process (job specific)
II.  Operating Procedures applicable to each job
III. Steps for each operating phase including:
     -  Initial Startup
     -  Normal Operation
     -  Temporary Operation
     -  Emergency Operation
     -  Emergency Shutdown
     -  Normal Shutdown
     -  Startup following a Turnaround
     -  Startup following an Emergency Shutdown
IV. Operating Limits and consequences of deviation
V.  Safety and Health considerations
VI. Safety Systems and their functions

Personnel may also take part in the Facility's Emergency Response Team by completing specific training and testing.  The Facility utilizes trained onsite personnel to respond in case of emergency. The Human Resources and Operations Departments are responsible for implementing the Operator Training porti

on of the Prevention Program.


CONTRACTORS

The Santa Maria Facility employs numerous Contractors to perform unit maintenance and construction. The Facility outlines safety and training programs for Contractors.  Contractors are trained by onsite personnel about the hazards of the Process, safety procedures and equipment requirements, and the emergency response procedures onsite prior to commencement of work.  Contractors performing work at the Facility must complete the Facility Safety Orientation Program.  The Safety Orientation Program includes Rules of Conduct, Emergency Procedures, HazCom, PSM, Hearing Conservation, and applicable TSCA and RCRA topics.  Contractor companies must also provide safety training to their own employees as required by State and Federal Regulations.  Contractors are advised of the Facility's Communication Program. The Facility screens Contractors' own Safety Programs and safety performance prior to awarding contracts at the Facility.  Contractors must be approved via a qualification procedure.  Information regarding a Contractor's area of expertise, financial stability, safety history, safety and health policies and programs, employee training, regulatory compliance, insurance coverage and other areas of interest to the Facility are solicited prior to starting work at the Facility. Facility personnel periodically monitor Contractor performance to ensure that Contractors are fulfilling their conduct, training, and safety obligations. The Procurement Department and the Health & Safety Department are responsible for implementing the Contractors portion of the Prevention Program.


PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEWS (PSSRs)

The Santa Maria Facility conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the Process Safety Information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into

service.  This review provides an additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that supporting systems are operationally ready.  The PSSR is conducted as part of the Facility's Management of Change process just prior to startup and final acceptance of the project.  Department Supervisors review and approve their department checklists to ensure that the project is safe and operable.  Technical Services, Operations, Maintenance, Reliability, and Environmental Department Supervisors review and sign off on their respective checklists prior to startup. The Operations/Technical Services Department is responsible for implementing the Pre-Startup Safety Review portion of the Prevention Program.


MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

The Santa Maria Facility has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems, in a safe operating condition.  The main parts of the program are outlined below.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.

Program Section  -  Purpose

-  Code Compliance  -  Ensuring that process equipment is designed with the appropriate codes and industry standards.
-  Training  -  Ensuring that inspectors and operators are inspecting properly and are alert to abnormal conditions and corrosion/wear.  Training also involves maintenance procedures and training for proper maintenance of process equipment.
-  Inspection Procedures  -  Ensuring that inspections are consistent throughout the Facility and that all inspections are conducted safely.
-  Inspection Schedules  -  Ensuring that inspections are conducted as frequently as required by code or by equipment service/life time, and providing a baseline for corrosion rates.
-  Quality Assurance  -  Ensuring that changes and equipment replacements/upgrades are compliant with

code requirements and meet design specifications prior to startup.
    
The Mechanical Integrity Program is maintained by many Facility departments. Each department has responsibilities for different program aspects.  The equipment type and primary responsibility are outlined below.

     Equipment Type - Primary Responsibility

     Pressure Vessels - Inspection Department
     Heat Exchangers - Inspection Department
     Fired Heaters & Boilers - Inspection Department
     Piping & Fittings - Inspection Department
     Pressure Relief Devices - Inspection Department
     Storage Tanks - Inspection Department
     Rotating Equipment - Maintenance
     Valves - Maintenance
     Control Valves - Maintenance
     Instrumentation - Maintenance
     Electrical Equipment - Maintenance
     Structures/Foundations - Technical Services
     Hoists/Lifts/Materials Handling - Maintenance
     Fire Protection Systems - Health & Safety

The Mechanical Integrity Program covers equipment used to process, control, and store hazardous chemicals and assigns responsibility for the inspection and testing of such equipment. Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provides a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels).  If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service, or a Management of Change Team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment. The Santa Maria Facility incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use, and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.  The Technical Servic

es Department is responsible for implementing the Mechanical Integrity portion of the Prevention Program.


SAFE WORK PRACTICES & HOT WORK PERMITTING

The Santa Maria Facility provides a safe and healthy work place for the employees, contractors, visitors, and the community surrounding the Facility.  Safe work practices are in place to ensure that potentially hazardous activities are conducted safely. These safe work practices and procedures, along with training of affected personnel and Contractors, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.  Examples of safe work practices at the Santa Maria Facility include:

-  Tracking and control of the entry/presence/exit of employees and contractors into and out of the Facility and process units
-  A hazardous energy procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance (i.e., Lock/Tag/Try)
-  A procedure for safe removal of hazardous material before process piping or equipment is opened
-  A permit and procedure to control spark producing activities (i.e., Hot Work Permitting)
-  A permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space 

In addition to the Safe Work Practices outlined above, the Santa Maria Facility conducts regular Physical Conditions Audits to ensure compliance with Federal, State, local regulations, and Company loss control requirements.  The intent of the inspections is to:

-  Determine the effectiveness of the Facility's loss control system
-  Establish a level of compliance
-  Identify hazards and substandard conditions/practices for correction
-  Give recognition for exceptional compliance

Specific physical conditions inspections are conducted for each Process Unit, storage and tankage areas, maintenance facilities, warehouse, laboratory, office buildings, and contractor work sites. The Health & Safety Department administers the Safe Work Practice p

ortion of the Prevention Program.


MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

The Santa Maria Facility has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes.  The Management of Change procedure has been implemented in order to ensure that installations and changes to equipment are made in a manner that ensures safety and operability.  Personnel and Organizational Changes that could impact Health and Safety program effectiveness are also managed through the MOC process. Whenever equipment or installations are modified, new facilities are added, or process changes are necessary, a review by appropriate Engineering, Operations, Maintenance, Safety, and Environmental personnel is conducted.  For all changes, a Management of Change proposal is submitted for consideration through the KMS Resolution Tracker database system. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other Facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being placed into service. Changes are reviewed to:

-  Ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, and
-  Verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change

Projects proceed from the initial MOC proposal through a planned sequence of signoffs designed to ensure that affected parties are aware of the changes being implemented.  Affected Process Safety Information, including chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, is updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.  Prior to startup, the MOC procedure requires a Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) described above. The Technical Services Department is responsible for implementing the Management of Change portion of the Prevention Program.


INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

The Santa Maria Facility promptly in

vestigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. Notification of incidents is made immediately so appropriate action can be taken and investigations can be initiated.  Investigation activities are directed toward defining the facts and circumstances related to the event, determining the causes, and developing corrective measures.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are available to employees (and contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Investigations of serious incidents include Management, Engineering, Operations, and Health & Safety staff as appropriate. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years so that the reports can be reviewed during future Unit Process Hazard Analyses.  The Santa Maria Facility uses the IMPACT database incident reporting and tracking system. The Health & Safety Department is responsible for coordinating the Incident Investigation portion of the Prevention Program.


COMPLIANCE AUDITS

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Santa Maria Facility periodically conducts audits to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits currently are conducted for RMP programs at least every three years.  The RMP Program and Hazard Assessment are included in the triennial audit. The audit includes written program reviews, field verifications, and interviews with field, staff and management personnel. Regulatory agencies may also perform periodic compliance audits of the Facility and its programs. Audit Findings are forwarded to appropriate Facility personnel for tracking and resolution.  The final resolution of each Finding is documented.  The Health & Safety Department is responsible for implement

ing the Compliance Audit portion of the Prevention Program.


CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The processes at the Santa Maria Facility have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all processes at the Facility. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors. Some of the administrative programs to prevent, detect, or mitigate an incident at the Facility are presented above.  Specific safety equipment and procedures, known as safeguards, are in place at the Facility.  These safeguards are listed as part of the Process Hazard Analyses, Process Safety Information, and in the Operating Procedures.  Some examples of safeguards are presented below:

Release Detection
-  Hydrogen Sulfide detectors with alarms
-  Facility Alarm System to notify personnel in case of emergency

Release Containment/Control
-  Process relief valves to protect pressure vessels
-  Operating materials recovery system with process flare to incinerate excess materials from the process
-  Manual and automatic valves to permit isolation of the process
-  Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters
-  "Fail-Safe" valves to isolate equipment in case of unplanned events such as power failures and earthquakes
-  Containment around tanks and process areas to contain liquid materials
-  Backup power supply for critical process equipment
-  Tank vapor recovery system to contain hazardous tank vapors

Release Mitigation
-  Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
-  Deluge system for specific equipment
-  Trained emergency response personnel
-  Personal Protective Equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
-  Blast-resistant buildings to help protect control systems and personnel
-  Backup fire protection equipment


FIVE YEAR ACCIDE

NT HISTORY

The EPA RMP rule requires facilities to compile a Five-Year Accident History for certain releases that exceed reporting requirements.  The Facility documents and tracks incidents and near misses that occur within the Facility.  

The Santa Maria Facility did not experience any incidents in the past five years that qualify for reporting in the five-year accident history. 


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Phillips 66 Santa Maria Facility has adopted the Incident Command System to ensure a safe and effective response to Facility emergencies.  The Emergency Response Plan (ERP) describes the organization, procedures, and equipment for an emergency response. The Facility is prepared to respond to emergencies internally, with support from outside authorities if needed. The Facility's Emergency Response Team (ERT) responds to all Facility emergency incidents.  If Initial Response personnel cannot mitigate the incident, an Advanced Response is implemented utilizing additional Facility personnel and external assistance.  Emergencies requiring response by the Facility include:

-  Fire or potential fire
-  Gas or Oil Release
-  Serious injury/illness
-  Release of toxic chemical
-  Emergency requiring search and rescue

The Facility has prepared for onsite emergencies through a variety of training drills and procedures.  As part of the Emergency Response Plan - Pre-Emergency Planning & Training Program the Facility has provided:

-  Personnel training for firefighting, hazard communication, incident command, first aid/CPR, SCBA, and hazardous waste worker training to prevent and respond to emergencies.
-  Evacuation routes and safe areas for all Facility personnel, visitors, and Contractors, as well as attendance and check in procedures.
-  Availability of external assistance of local fire and rescue, medical, and environmental clean-up organizations to provide assistance during advanced responses.
-  Emergency equipment and supplies maintain

ed throughout the Facility to respond to anticipated incidents.
-  Communications networks, including back-up systems, established for internal and external communications.
-  Pre-emergency plans, including ongoing hazard specific pre-fire plans, developed to provide guidance in responding to emergencies in an organized and effective manner to protect onsite personnel, surrounding communities, and the environment.
-  Emergency response drills to ensure efficient response by onsite personnel.

The Santa Maria Facility supplies Emergency Response Team members with respiratory protection and personal protective clothing for use while responding to emergencies.  This equipment is designed to allow the ERT to work safely during an emergency.  A variety of firefighting and spill containment materials are located at the Facility or stationed nearby for response to emergencies. Equipment is inspected, maintained, and replaced regularly to ensure dependable performance. The Facility uses different systems to disseminate emergency instructions and information within the Facility.  Those systems include:

-  Plant Alarms (Facility General Alarm, Sulfur Plant Alarm, H2S Gas Release Alarm, Evacuation Alarm)
-  Emergency Public Address System
-  Internal Portable Radio Network
-  Plant and External Telephones

The Facility's initial response to an emergency is essential to successfully control an incident without the need for advanced response.  By controlling an incident during initial response, the Facility reduces the risk to the initial responders, ERT, operating personnel, the public, and the environment.  The Facility has predefined emergency response responsibilities, which personnel fill in case of an emergency.  Those positions include:

     Incident Commander
     Command Staff Coordinator
     Public Information Officer
     Communications Officer
     Liaison Officer
     Operations Chief
     Staging Support
     Planning Chief
     Planning Su

pport
     Logistics Chief
     Logistics Support
     Safety Officer
     Finance Chief

When the Incident Commander believes that additional Phillips 66 emergency response personnel are required to handle an emergency, the IC will direct the Communications Officer to contact standby shift personnel and will notify the Security Office to activate an automated personnel emergency notification system.  The Incident Commander makes the determination when external assistance or reporting is required.  The Facility may request assistance from any of the following agencies:

     Arroyo Grande Hospital
     California Highway Patrol
     San Luis Obispo County Sheriff
     Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI)
     Pacific Gas & Electric
     Union Pacific Railroad
     San Luis Obispo County Emergency Services
     California Office of Emergency Services
     National Response Center
     San Luis Obispo County CAL FIRE
     San Luis Obispo County CUPA

External assistance will normally be requested only during advanced emergencies at the instruction of the Incident Commander.  The Facility has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate officials and emergency response organizations.  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  Emergency situations that may endanger human health or the environment outside the Facility will be reported to the Local Emergency Services Organization (San Luis Obispo County Emergency Services).  They, in turn, may notify appropriate State and local response organizations to respond to the scene and lead offsite evacuation efforts.

In the event of an uncontrolled release of potentially toxic chemicals or flammable materials, the Facility will perform emergency exposure air monitoring in addition to the emergency response efforts.  This monitoring will be conducted primarily to help quantify potential atmospheric expo

sures to the community and to help identify protection requirements.

The Facility is also prepared to deal with offsite incidents potentially affecting the Facility. The nature of the emergency shall dictate the degree of response:  Minimal, Moderate, or Advanced.  The responses are outlined below:

-  Minimal Response: Incident requires minimal onsite response, typically Security
-  Moderate Response: Incident requires resources such as Security, EMT personnel, and ambulance or law enforcement notification
-  Advanced Response: Incident such as wildland fire, flood or earthquake, requiring an advanced response of the ICS System, potentially using outside resources like the San Luis Obispo County CAL FIRE, San Luis Obispo County CUPA, California Highway Patrol, local and county fire and paramedic resources, and law enforcement.

A copy of the Facility's Emergency Response Plan is provided to the local emergency response agencies.  The Plan provides detailed information on the Facility's emergency response organization, procedures and resources.  Facility emergency response personnel periodically meet with local agency representatives to discuss response capabilities and to look for new ways to improve overall emergency response preparedness.
  
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Facility is committed to ensuring compliance with RMP programs, and continuously improving our safety programs.  The Facility continuously seeks and evaluates methods to improve the safety of its operations.  Recommendations from audits, incident investigations, PHA's, equipment tests and inspections, preventive maintenance programs, and employee suggestions form the basis for many of these opportunities.   The Mechanical Engineering and Inspection Department has well established inspection programs for piping, vessels and tanks that are consistent with American Petroleum Institute (API) Inspection Codes, CCR Petroleum Safety Orders, and company inspection practices.  Improv
